meeting_annotations.speaker: Alison Ondrus
meeting_annotations.transcript: Nice. I'll jump in on that too a little bit. Because Abby, you know, actually Jeff Moore was the advisor of the person that that Abby and I are consulting with on our mechanophore project. Yes, it's always very very small world. Um but to follow up on what Abby was saying, I think, you know, that's what I really like about the project, you know, seeing the forces of life is what we called it that we are, you know, working on with the support of the CMC is that we really have tried, I think with our team to trace sort of span the the different scales where, you know, we have Abby's computation where we're looking at, you know, even like the forces between bonds in an individual tether between what's pulling and what's fixed in the cell and the extracellular environment. And then, you know, we have these chemical tools that we've developed that fluoresce or create a signal once we've passed a certain force which is definitely at the level of, you know, cell and protein type forces. And then we're working with uh Ross Wang who's also, you know, here this year too and on our project where the ultimate goal is to then look at sort of a macro scale or at least a cellular scale phenomenon of cell migration and take it all the way from sort of the forces that bonds are experiencing in this tether to the sort of phenotypic output of that one protein force that's being felt to what the phenomenon is on the cellular scale of migrating. So I think like that's definitely something that came out of this meeting and we're looking to to try to make a little bit of inroads at least on this specific topic between the nano scale and the macro scale. That's fantastic. Yeah, so I thought maybe a progress report or plug our project or something but um switching gears a little bit to my own lab, one thing that hasn't been brought up yet that we're really obsessed with is um metabolism and signaling metabolites that are exchanged between different cell types, different organs and even different species. So it's really hot right now as you know the microbiome and metabolites that are being secreted by this whole you know universe of microbes in our gut and how that affects our health. Um but it also shows up in sort of endocrine signaling within tissues where you have the immune system is something that we work on that communicates metabolically between different immune cell types and spurs all sorts of different, you know, differentiation and response processes. So my questions with respect to metabolism would be, you know, how how do we sort of trace the origins and receptors of signaling metabolites either between uh cell types, species and organs. And then I guess a dream that I had was, you know, how do we engineer technologies where we might be able to say, you know, use a bump and hole technique so we can create these labeled signaling metabolites in one species or one cell type and then trace them as they travel to different organs and actually get to the molecular level and see what receptors they're interacting with and how that sort of rewires all of these broader signaling pathways.
